energy_formulas_3.subtitle: Dimensional Analysis, Symbolic Solutions, Proportionality
energy_formulas_3.objective: Deduce units of formulas for energy; Symbolically solve the formulas for KE, GPE, and EPE; use proportionality to determine changes in energy as other quantities change.
energy_formulas_3.content: All forms of energy have the same units in terms of kilograms, meters, and seconds; proportionality can be used to easily find quantities of energy.

semi_qualitative_conservation_of_energy.title: Semi-Qualitative Conservation of Energy
semi_qualitative_conservation_of_energy.objective: Answer quantitative questions using the conservation of energy by concept alone without resorting to plugging in numbers.

work_done_on_system.title: Work Done on a System
work_done_on_system.objective: Determine the work done on a system by considering changes in energy.
work_done_on_system.content: Work done on a system is the change in the total energy of that system.

symbolic_energy.title: Symbolic Energy
symbolic_energy.objective: Describe the transfer of the energy within a system symbolically; explain equations derived; use equations derived to find useful equations and functions
symbolic_energy.content: A physicist can derive useful new equations by using the conservation of energy symbolically

vertical_spring_system.title: Vertical Spring System
vertical_spring_system.objective: Numerically analyze change in energy on a system including a mass on a vertical spring in which work is done on the system by an outside force and by friction.

algebraic_energy_analysis_1.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 1
algebraic_energy_analysis_1.subtitle: Pendulums
algebraic_energy_analysis_1.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a pendulum system as it swings; write statements regarding the energy of the pendulum-earth system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the pendulum using the Conservation of Energy.

algebraic_energy_analysis_2.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 2
algebraic_energy_analysis_2.subtitle: Horizontal Springs
algebraic_energy_analysis_2.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a horizontal spring system as it moves; write statements regarding the energy of the mass-spring system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the spring using the Conservation of Energy.

algebraic_energy_analysis_3.title: Algebraic Energy Analysis 3
algebraic_energy_analysis_3.subtitle: Vertical Springs
algebraic_energy_analysis_3.objective: Symbolically analyze the energy of a vertical spring system as it moves; write statements regarding the energy of the mass-spring-earth system; symbolically determine crucial values regarding the spring using the Conservation of Energy.

spidermans_energy.title: Spiderman's Energy
spidermans_energy.objective: Analyze the potential energy of a fast moving spring that stretches as it falls.

work_power_formulas.title: Work and Power Formulas
work_power_formulas.objective: Solve the work and power formulas, including in situations in which an object does not move.
work_power_formulas.content: Work is equal to force times distance; if an object does not move, no work is done; power is equal to work divided by time elapsed while down that work.

defining_mechanical_energy.title: Defining Mechanical Energy
defining_mechanical_energy.objective: Write the definition of mechanical energy, recognize examples of mechanical and non-mechanical energies, sum mechanical energy of objects with several different types of energy.
defining_mechanical_energy.content: Kinetic energy and the forms of potential energy that can be gained by doing work are called mechanical energy; gravitational and elastic potential energy are a component of mechanical energy; chemical, electrochemical, and nuclear potential energies are not a part of mechanical energy.

is_work_done.title: Is work done?
is_work_done.objective: Identify situations in which positive work, negative work, and zero work is done.
is_work_done.content: If an object moves in the direction of the force on an object, positive work is done; if an object moves in the opposite direction as a force on an object, negative work is done; if an object moves in a direction perpendicular to the force on an object, no work is done; if an object does not move no work is done.

weightlifter_problem.title: The Weightlifter Problem
weightlifter_problem.objective: Analyze how work and power are different for weightlifters lifting weights at different speeds.
weightlifter_problem.content: A weightlifter lifting more weight ot a taller height is doing more work; a weightlifter lifting the same weight to the same height but in less time does the same work but has more power.

conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.title: Conservative vs. Non-conservative Forces
conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.objective: Identify conservative and non-conservative forces and explain how they can be analyzed differently.
conservative_vs_nonconservative_forces.content: A conservative force does not cause a system to lose mechanical energy; gravity and the elastic force are conservative forces; friction and air resistance are non-conservative forces

work_energy_theorem_A.title: The Work-Energy Theorem A
work_energy_theorem_A.objective: Create Formulas based on the work-energy theorem and use them to solve dynamics and kinematics problems.
work_energy_theorem_A.content: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the work done a system equals to the change in mechanical energy of a system; physicists can use the work formula to calculate work done and then use this value to calculate quantities of kinetic and/or potential energy.
work_energy_theorem_A.limits: In this quiz, each type of potential energy is considered and the system is not rigorously defined yet.

work_energy_theorem_B.title: The Work-Energy Theorem B
work_energy_theorem_B.objective: Create Formulas based on the work-energy theorem and use them to solve dynamics and kinematics problems.
work_energy_theorem_B.content: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the work done a system equals to the change in mechanical energy of a system; physicists can use the work formula to calculate work done and then use this value to calculate quantities of kinetic and/or potential energy.
work_energy_theorem_B.limits: In this quiz, each type of potential energy is considered and the system is not rigorously defined yet.

force_position_graphs_1.title: Force-Position Graphs 1: Calculating Work
force_position_graphs_1.objective: Calculate Work using a force-position graph.
force_position_graphs_1.content: The work done on an object is equal to the area under the curve of a force-position graph of that object.

multiple_viewpoints_1.title: Multiple Viewpoints 1: Block on a Ramp
multiple_viewpoints_1.objective: Analyze, algebraically and graphically, a block on a frictionless ramp with different definitions of the system and surroundings.
multiple_viewpoints_1.content: When using the work-energy theorem, a physicist defines a specific system and all forces internal and external to that system; by redefining the system, the physicist changes which forces and which types of potential energy are used in the analysis

multiple_viewpoints_2.title: Multiple Viewpoints 2: Comet
multiple_viewpoints_2.objective: Analyze, algebraically and graphically, a comet orbiting the sun with different definitions of the system and the surroundings.
multiple_viewpoints_2.content: When using the work-energy theorem, a physicist defines a specific system and all forces internal and external to that system; by redefining the system, the physicist changes which forces and which types of potential energy are used in the analysis

force_position_graphs_2.title: Force-Position Graphs 2: Work-Energy Theorem
force_position_graphs_2.objective: Use a force-position graph together with the work-energy theorem to find dynamic and kinematic quantities.
force_position_graphs_2.content: A physicist, by understanding the definition of work and the work-energy theorem, can learn useful quantities from a force-position graph of an object.

prove_work_energy_theorem.title: Prove the Work Energy Theorem: Special Case
prove_work_energy_theorem.objective: Algebraically prove the work-energy theorem when acceleration is constant.
prove_work_energy_theorem.content: For an object moving with a constant acceleration, the work-energy theorem can be demonstrated by combining Newton's Laws of motion with the kinematic equations.

derive_potential_energy_formulas.title: Derive Potential Energy Formulas
derive_potential_energy_formulas.objective: Use the work-energy theorem to derive potential energy formulas.
derive_potential_energy_formulas.content: The formulas we use for potential energy can be derived from the work-energy theorem.

multiple_viewpoints_3.title: Multiple Viewpoints 3: Spidey String
multiple_viewpoints_3.objective: Analyze, algebraically and graphically, Spiderman swinging from his spidey-string with different definitions of the system and surroundings.
multiple_viewpoints_3.content: As Spiderman swings from building to building, he gains and loses kinetic energy, his string gains and loses elastic potential energy, and the spiderman-earth system gains and loses gravitational potential energy; a physicist can analyze this motion using multiple different systems as a point of view and find the same underlying result.

three_types_motion.title: Three Types of Motion
three_types_motion.objective: Understand the difference between three different types of motion: constant velocity, uniformly accelerating, and non-uniformly accelerating
three_types_motion.content: Constant velocity motion is analyzed with the speed formula, uniformly accelerated motion is analyzed with the four kinematic equations, and non-uniformly accelerated motion is analyzed with calculus.

falling_1.title: Falling 1
falling_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
falling_1.objective: Solve numeric problems about objects falling down and objects thrown downwards.
falling_1.content: Objects falling downwards have an acceleration of 9/8 m/s^2 downwards and follow the four kinematic equations

parabolic_arcs.title: Parabolic Arcs
parabolic_arcs.objective: Draw qualitative diagrams of objects in projectile motion; define free-fall
parabolic_arcs.content: All objects in projectile motion follow downward facing parabolic arcs; all objects that have only gravity acting on them, no matter what direction they are moving, are in free-fall.

falling_2.title: Falling 2
falling_2.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy Analysis
falling_2.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object falling downward; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object falling downward; demonstrate how an object falling downward follows the conservation of energy.
falling_2.content: Physicists can analyze an object falling downward through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

pop_up_1.title: Pop-Up 1
pop_up_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
pop_up_1.objective: Solve numeric problems about objects falling down and objects thrown directly upwards.
pop_up_1.content: Objects thrown upwards have an acceleration of 9/8 m/s^2 downwards, have an initial velocity that is upwards, and follow the four kinematic equations

falling_3.title: Falling 3
falling_3.subtitle: Functional and Algebraic Analysis
falling_3.objective: Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is falling; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
falling_3.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object falling downwards.

pop_up_2.title: Pop-Up 2
pop_up_2.subtitle: Numeric Analysis with Quadratic Equation
pop_up_2.objective: Solve numerical pop-up problems which require the use of the quadratic equation.
pop_up_2.content: When an object is thrown directly upwards and lands at a different vertical position than it began, a physicist must use the quadratic formula to solve the necessary kinematic equations and describe the motion of the ball.

pop_up_3.title: Pop-Up 3
pop_up_3.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy-based Analysis
pop_up_3.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object thrown directly upward; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object thrown directly upward; demonstrate how an object thrown directly upward follows the conservation of energy.
pop_up_3.content: Physicists can analyze an object thrown directly upward through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

horizontal_launch_1.title: Horizontal Launch 1
horizontal_launch_1.subtitle: Numeric Analysis
horizontal_launch_1.objective: Solve for important kinematic quantities when an object is launched horizontally.
horizontal_launch_1.content: When an object is launched horizontally, it moves at a constant speed in the horizontal dimension and accelerates downward in the vertical dimension; physicists can use the kinematic equations to analyze the motion of this object.

bullet_drop_conundrum.title: Bullet Drop Conundrum
bullet_drop_conundrum.objective: Explain, in words, how a bullet dropped and a bullet fired from a gun reach the ground at the same time; analyze the an object launched upward out of the sunroof of a moving car.
bullet_drop_conundrum.content: Motion in the horizontal dimension does not affect motion in the vertical dimension, therefore an object fired horizontally, such as a bullet, falls at precisely the same rate as an object merely dropped

horizontal_launch_2.title: Horizontal Launch 2
horizontal_launch_2.subtitle: Kinematic, Dynamic, and Energy Analysis
horizontal_launch_2.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object fired horizontally; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object fired horizontally; demonstrate how an object fired horizontally follows the conservation of energy.
horizontal_launch_2.content: Physicists can analyze an object fired horizontally through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

cannon_problems_1.title: Cannon Problems 1
cannon_problems_1.subtitle: Concepts and Numeric Analysis
cannon_problems_1.objective: Conceptually explain the motion in each dimension of an object launched at an angle; use this information to solve for relevant numeric quantities.
cannon_problems_1.content: An object fired at an angle moves forward with a constant velocity in the horizontal dimension and moves identically to an object thrown directly upward in the vertical dimension.

cannon_problems_2.title: Cannon Problems 2
cannon_problems_2.subtitle: On Different Levels
cannon_problems_2.objective: Solve a cannon problem in which the cannonball lands on a different vertical level than it began.
cannon_problems_2.content: When a cannonball fired at an angle lands on a different vertical level than where it began, a physicist must use the quadratic formula to determine necessary kinematic quantities.

pop_up_4.title: Pop-Up 4: Symbolic Algebra
pop_up_4.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
pop_up_4.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is thrown directly into the air; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is thrown directly upward; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
pop_up_4.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object thrown directly upwards.

horizontal_launch_3.title: Horizontal Launch 3
horizontal_launch_3.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
horizontal_launch_3.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is fired horizontally; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is fired horizontally; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
horizontal_launch_3.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object fired horizontally.

cannon_problems_3.title: Cannon Problems 3
cannon_problems_3.subtitle: Kinematic and Dynamic Analysis
cannon_problems_3.objective: Create qualitative kinematic graphs of an object fired at an angle; use Newton's Laws to analyze the dynamics of an object fired at an angle; demonstrate how an object fired at an angle follows the conservation of energy.
cannon_problems_3.content: Physicists can analyze an object fired at an angle through kinematic, dynamic, or energy-based methods and find consistent results.

banana_cannon.title: The Banana Cannon
banana_cannon.objective: Qualitatively explain how gravity affects horizontally moving and non-horizontally moving objects in the same way and apply this principle to simply aiming a cannon at a falling target with a cannon.
banana_cannon.content: A cannon is aimed directly at a target that begins falling immediately when the cannon fires; the cannon will always strike the target because gravity affects the projectile and the target in the same way.

cannon_problems_4.title: Cannon Problems 4
cannon_problems_4.subtitle: Symbolic and Functional Analysis
cannon_problems_4.objective: Symbolically solve for relevant quantities when an object is fired at an angle; Defend answers using dimensional analysis; Create functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities acting on an object that is fired at an angle; demonstrate how these functions are correct in known cases.
cannon_problems_4.content: Physicists can solve equations algebraically to write functions that describe the kinematic, dynamic, and energy-based quantities of an object fired at an angle.

aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.title: Aim a cannon with laser pointers.
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.objective: Determine a method to aim a cannon and expect a direct hit with laser pointers.
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.content: With multiple angles pointing to a particular object, physicists can use trigonometry and geometry to locate a particular object in 1-D, 2-D, or 3-D space
aiming_cannon_laser_pointers.note: Connected to the 'placing an object in three-dimensional space' problem from the geometry unit.

wide_receiver_motion.title: Wide Receiver in Motion
wide_receiver_motion.objective: Devise a model that mathematical depicts how a quarterback hits a wide receiver running quickly with a parabolic pass.
wide_receiver_motion.content: Through careful mathematical analysis, a physicist can create a mathematical model that can guide someone to accomplish a complex task, such as hitting a moving target with a projectile motion.

vector_form_conversion.title: Vector Form Conversion
vector_form_conversion.objective: Convert a vector between standard form and component form and back

vector_component_addition.title: Vector Component Addition
vector_component_addition.objective: Add vectors and subtract vectors in multiple dimensions using component form.

dragging_at_angle_1.title: Dragging at an Angle 1: Kinetic Friction Only
dragging_at_angle_1.objective: Analyze the motion of a block dragged at an angle with only kinetic friction; explain why the drag influences the normal force.

hanging_sign_1.title: Hanging a Sign 1: Two Ropes
hanging_sign_1.objective: Draw a quantitative free-body diagram of a sign hanging from two ropes, both at an angle.

ramp_problems_1.title: Ramp Problems 1: No Friction
ramp_problems_1.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with either no friction or kinetic friction only.

ramp_problems_2.title: Ramp Problems 2: Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_2.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with either no friction or kinetic friction only.

dragging_at_angle_2.title: Dragging at an Angle 2: Static and Kinetic Friction
dragging_at_angle_2.objective: Analyze the motion of a block dragged at an angle under both static and kinetic friction.

hanging_sign_2.title: Hanging a Sign 2: Three Ropes
hanging_sign_2.objective: Draw a quantitative free-body diagram of a sign hanging from three ropes at angles.

ramp_problems_3.title: Ramp Problems 3: Static and Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_3.objective: Numerically analyze the motion of a block on a ramp with both static and kinetic friction.

ramp_problems_4.title: Ramp Problems 4: Algebraic with No Friction or Kinetic Friction
ramp_problems_4.objective: Algebraically model a block on a ramp without friction or only kinetic friction; use proportionality to make predictions regarding the model

ramp_problems_x.title: Ramp Problems X
ramp_problems_x.subtitle: Ramp Conservation of Energy
ramp_problems_x.objective: Demonstrate that the conservation of energy is consistent with the laws of dynamics for an object on a ramp without friction and with friction.

dragging_at_angle_3.title: Dragging at an Angle 3: Algebraic Solutions
dragging_at_angle_3.objective: Algebraically model a block being dragged at an angle; create algebraic conditions for the block to experience different types of motion.

ramp_problems_5.title: Ramp Problems 5: Algebraic with Kinetic and Static Friction
ramp_problems_5.objective: Algebraically model a block on a ramp with both static and kinetic friction

pulling_a_cordon.title: Pulling a Cordon
pulling_a_cordon.objective: Create an algebraic model of a person pulling on a cordon rope.

ramp_problems_6.title: Ramp Problems 6: Dragging and Object while on a ramp
ramp_problems_6.objective: Algebraically model a block being dragged on a ramp with friction.

2D_dynamics_level_6.title: 2-D Dynamics Level 6
2D_dynamics_level_6.objective: Create models using the principles of 2-dimensional dynamics.

momentum_formula.title: The Momentum Formula
momentum_formula.objective: Use the momentum formula to solve numerical problems.

memorize_conservation_of_momentum.title: Memorize the Conservation of Momentum
memorize_conservation_of_momentum.objective: Memorize, word for word, the conservation of momentum.
memorize_conservation_of_momentum.content: During any process, the total momentum before the process equals the total momentum after the process.

conservation_of_momentum_1.title: Conservation of Momentum 1
conservation_of_momentum_1.subtitle: Two Cars
conservation_of_momentum_1.objective: Use the conservation of momentum to solve simple collision problems with the aid of a table.
conservation_of_momentum_1.content: When two cars collide, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision; this information can be used to find useful information about the cars

conservation_of_momentum_2.title: Conservation of Momentum 2
conservation_of_momentum_2.subtitle: Perfectly Inelastic Collisions
conservation_of_momentum_2.objective: Use the conservation of momentum to analyze crashes in which two objects stick together.
conservation_of_momentum_2.content: When two cars crash and stick together, it is called a perfectly inelastic collision; a perfectly inelastic collision can also be analyzed using the principles of conservation of momentum.

conservation_of_momentum_3.title: Conservation of Momentum 3
conservation_of_momentum_3.subtitle: Head-On Collisions
conservation_of_momentum_3.objective: Use the conservation of momentum and guiding tables to solve problems involving cars moving in different directions.
conservation_of_momentum_3.content: When two cars are moving in different directions, physicists represent direction with the sign of the velocity.

conservation_of_momentum_4.title: Conservation of Momentum 4
conservation_of_momentum_4.subtitle: Explosions
conservation_of_momentum_4.objective: Use the conservation of momentum and guiding tables to analyze explosions.
conservation_of_momentum_4.content: The total momentum before an explosion equals the total momentum after the explosion.

collision_formula_derivation.title: Collision Formula Derivation
collision_formula_derivation.objective: Represent each situation involving conservation of momentum with an algebraic formula and explain what each term of that formula represents.
collision_formula_derivation.content: Physicists use the conservation of momentum to create a formula specific to individual situations.

conservation_of_momentum_5.title: Conservation of Momentum 5
conservation_of_momentum_5.objective: Use an algebraic formula to solve problems involving the conservation of momentum with information and method is not clearly given.
conservation_of_momentum_5.content: Physicists invent and solve formulas using the conservation of momentum to find useful information regarding a collision.

collision_energy.title: Collision Energy
collision_energy.objective: Given a collision or explosion, analyze the collision quantitatively, determine if kinetic energy is lost, gained, or conserved; analyze the source of work done on a system.
collision_energy.content: While momentum is always conserved in a collision or explosion, energy can be gained or lost depending upon the individual situation.

conservation_of_momentum_6.title: Conservation of Momentum 6
conservation_of_momentum_6.subtitle: Symbolic Analysis
conservation_of_momentum_6.objective: Solve for an algebraic solution to collision and explosion problems; prove solutions are dimensionally correct; use proportionality to analyze solutions
conservation_of_momentum_6.content: Physicists will often derive formulas based on the conservation of momentum, solve them algebraically, and theorize regarding relevant proportionality relationships.

elastic_collisions.title: Elastic Collisions
elastic_collisions.objective: Define elastic and inelastic collisions; recognize common elastic and inelastic collisions; numerically analyze objects undergoing an elastic collision
elastic_collisions.content: In an elastic collision, the kinetic energy before the collision equals the kinetic energy after the collision; this principle gives physicists another formula from which to find information regarding the collision.

advanced_pool_ball_collision.title: Advanced Pool Ball Collision
advanced_pool_ball_collision.objective: Derive formulas that explain pool ball collisions and use relate these formulas to the actual reality in a pool ball collision.

newtons_cradle.title: Newton's Cradle
newtons_cradle.objective: Use the conservation of momentum to explain how a Newton's Cradle works.

totally_inelastic_collision_energy_loss.title: Totally Inelastic Collision Energy Loss
totally_inelastic_collision_energy_loss.objective: Determine a formula for kinetic energy lost in the case of a totally inelastic collision; apply this formula to several possible situations

tennis_ball_basketball.title: The Tennis Ball and the Basketball
tennis_ball_basketball.objective: Create an algebraic model for the motion of a tennis ball dropped on top of basketball (resulting in an elastic collision between then)

impulse_formula_1.title: Impulse Formula 1
impulse_formula_1.objective: Solve straightforward numerical problems using the impulse formula.

impulse_concepts.title: Impulse Concepts
impulse_concepts.objective: Answer real-world written questions by referring to the impulse formula; describe whath the term 'breaking a fall' means.

dynamic_graphs_1.title: Dynamic Graphs 1
dynamic_graphs_1.subtitle: Introducing Dynamic Graphs
dynamic_graphs_1.objective: Qualitatively relate simple (1-2 step) momentum-time and force-time graphs; answer quantitative questions on momentum graphs

impulse_formula_3.title: Impulse Formula 3
impulse_formula_3.subtitle: Algebraic Proof
impulse_formula_3.objective: Prove the impulse formula is equivalent to Newton's Second Law.

dynamic_graphs_2.title: Dynamic Graphs 2
dynamic_graphs_2.objective: Quantitatively relate momentum-time graphs to net-force-time graphs.

dynamic_graphs_3.title: Dynamic Graphs 3
dynamic_graphs_3.objective: Quantitatively relate all five kinematic and dynamic graphs: position-time, velocity-time, acceleration-time, momentum-time, and net-force time.

kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 1
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_1.objective: Relate the five 'time' graphs of kinematic and dynamic quantities: position, velocity, acceleration, momentum, force.

impulse_formula_4.title: Impulse Formula 4: Proportionality and Inferences
impulse_formula_4.objective: Analyze impulse by using proportionality; make real world inferences using this analysis.

kinematic_dynamics_graphs_2.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 2
kinematic_dynamics_graphs_2.objective: Quantitatively relate the five graphs of kinematic and dynamic values.

kinematic_dynamic_graphs_3.title: Kinematic and Dynamic Graphs 3
kinematic_dynamic_graphs_3.objective: Create quantitative kinematic and dynamic graphs based on a complex real world description.

circular_motion_basics.title: Circular Motion Basics
circular_motion_basics.objective: Draw objects in circular motion; identify the centripetal force; predict what happens if the centripetal force is released

circular_vs_rotational_motion.title: Circular vs. Rotational Motion
circular_vs_rotational_motion.objective: Determine differences between circular and rotational motion.

circular_kinematics_1.title: Circular Kinematics 1: Finding Speed
circular_kinematics_1.objective: Find the speed of an object in circular motion.

newtons_model_circular_motion_1.title: Newton's Model for Circular Motion 1
newtons_model_circular_motion_1.objective: Explain why an object in circular motion is accelerating; extend Newton's Model to include turning

circular_motion_vectors.title: Circular Motion Vectors
circular_motion_vectors.objective: Identify the four relevant vectors for an object in circular motion: position, velocity, acceleration, and force.

centripetal_acceleration_formula_1.title: Centripetal Acceleration Formula 1
centripetal_acceleration_formula_1.objective: Use the centripetal acceleration formula alone.

centripetal_motion_counterintuitive.title: Newton's Model for Circular Motion 2: Counterintuitive Realities of Circular Motion
centripetal_motion_counterintuitive.objective: Using Newton's Model, explain why objects in a shopping bag do not fall out when it is flipped over and why the earth does not move towards the sun if it is attracted to it.

centripetal_acceleration_formula_2.title: Centripetal Acceleration Formula 2
centripetal_acceleration_formula_2.objective: Given a radius and period of circular motion, determine necessary quantitative information about that motion.

centripetal_acceleration_formula_3.title: Centripetal Acceleration Formula 3: Solving the Centripetal Acceleration Formula Algebraically
centripetal_acceleration_formula_3.objective: Solve the centripetal acceleration formula for each item and demonstrate answers are correct using dimensional analysis.

centripetal_acceleration_formula_4.title: Centripetal Acceleration Formula 4: Proportionality in the Centripetal Acceleration Formula
centripetal_acceleration_formula_4.objective: Use proportionality to find numerical answers with not all information given and to explain real life experiences with turning a car.

finding_mass_of_sun.title: Finding Mass of Sun
finding_mass_of_sun.objective: Use the formulas for centripetal acceleration and gravitation to find the mass of the sun and earth.

vertical_circles_1.title: Vertical Circles 1
vertical_circles_1.subtitle: Loop-de-loop problems
vertical_circles_1.objective: Analyze the forces in a vertical circle, for example, the forces on a pilot as he loops over.

proving_centripetal_acceleration_formula.title: Proving the Centripetal Acceleration Formula
proving_centripetal_acceleration_formula.objective: Argue the formula for centripetal acceleration is numerically accurate using a conceptual geometry and limit-based argument.

vertical_circles_2.title: Vertical Circles 2
vertical_circles_2.objective: Derive a formula relating angular position, velocity, and acceleration for an object moving in a vertical circle.

gravitron.title: The Gravitron
gravitron.objective: Analyze the forces acting on a person in the gravitron amusement park ride; describe why a person feels 'pressed into' the wall during the ride.

hula_hoop.title: The Hula Hoop
hula_hoop.objective: Develop a quantitative model to examine the motion of a hula hoop.

artificial_gravity_part_2.title: Artificial Gravity Part 2
artificial_gravity_part_2.objective: Develop a model of a space station in which people can walk around normally, as they would on earth, due to the dynamics of centripetal force.

circular_motion_trigonometry.title: Circular Motion Trigonometry
circular_motion_trigonometry.vision: Problems that require both circular motion and trigonometry: banking on a highway, using polar coordinates to describe motion

period_and_frequency_1.title: Period and Frequency 1
period_and_frequency_1.objective: Define and calculate period and frequency.

harmonic_v_linear_motion.title: Harmonic vs. Linear Motion
harmonic_v_linear_motion.objective: Define and give examples of harmonic and linear motion.

period_frequency_2.title: Period and Frequency 2
period_frequency_2.objective: Correctly use the formula T = 1 /f, including with proportionality

position_time_graphs_periodic_motion.title: Position-Time Graphs of Periodic Motion
position_time_graphs_periodic_motion.objective: Draw simple position-time graphs of periodic motion.

periodic_frequency_3.title: Period and Frequency 3: Specific Formulas
periodic_frequency_3.objective: Numerically solve the formulas for period and frequency of a spring or pendulum.

periodic_position_function.title: Periodic Position Function
periodic_position_function.objective: Use a trigonometric function to represent the position of an object in harmonic motion, wiht period and amplitude correct but phase not considered.

period_frequency_4.title: Period and Frequency 4: Symbolic Solutions Algebra
period_frequency_4.objective: Algebraically solve the period and frequency formulas for springs and pendulums

period_frequency_5.title: Period and Frequency 5: Proportionality
period_frequency_5.objective: Use proportionality to analyze the formulas for frequency and period of a pendulum.

periodic_position_function_2.title: Periodic Position Function 2
periodic_position_function_2.objective: Use trigonometric formulas to preresent the position of an object in harmonic motion, including correct amplitude, period, and phase.

spring_pendulum_energy_1.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 1
spring_pendulum_energy_1.objective: In diagrams or sentences, explain qualitatively how energy changes in a spring or pendulum; explain the 'pendulum nose' phenomnenon

hookes_law.title: Hooke's Law
hookes_law.objective: Use Hooke's Law to predict forces acting on a spring, and analyze Hooke's Law with proportionality.

newtons_model_pendulums.title: Newton's Model for Pendulums
newtons_model_pendulums.objective: Draw free-body diagrams of a pendulum at different points in its motion and relate these free-body didagrms tot he motion of the pendulum using Newton's Model.

newtons_model_springs.title: Newton's Model for Springs
newtons_model_springs.objective: Draw free-body diagrams of a pendulum at different points in its motion and relate these free-body didagrms tot he motion of the pendulum using Newton's Model.

spring_pendulum_energy_2.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 2: Energy Equations for Springs and Pendulums
spring_pendulum_energy_2.objective: Create equations of motion for springs and pendulums using the conservation of energy; explain the terms of these equations; defend these equations using dimensional analysis.

spring_pendulum_energy_3.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 3: Quantitative Energy Problems for Springs and Pendulums
spring_pendulum_energy_3.notes: Create and solve equations of motion for springs and pendulums using the conservation of energy.

spring_pendulum_energy_4.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 4: Energy Algebra for a Spring
spring_pendulum_energy_4.objective: Create an algebraically solve equations of motion for a spring from the conservation of energy; derive equations that relate amplitude and max-speed

spring_pendulum_energy_5.title: Spring and Pendulum Energy 5: Energy Algebra for a Pendulum
spring_pendulum_energy_5.objective: Create an algebraically solve equations of motion for a pendulum from the conservation of energy; derive equations that relate amplitude and max-speed

periodic_kinematic_functions_1.title: Periodic Kinematic Functions 1
periodic_kinematic_functions_1.objective: Using the periodic functions for position from the previous unit and the energy equations from level 3, derive velocity-time and acceleration-time kinematic equations for harmonic motion.
periodic_kinematic_functions_1.limits: Functions developed need not include phase or damping.

vertical_springs.title: Vertical Springs
vertical_springs.objective: Prove that a vertical spring works identically to a horizontal spring.

damping.title: Damping
damping.objective: Examine the effect of damping on the position-time graph of springs and pendulums.

periodic_kinematic_functions_2.title: Periodic Kinematic Functions 2
periodic_kinematic_functions_2.objective: Without using calculus, create position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs for simple harmonic motion in terms of amplitude and phase.
periodic_kinematic_functions_2.limits: Does not include damping or differential equations.

differential_equations_periodic_motion.title: Differential Equations for Periodic Motion
differential_equations_periodic_motion.notes: Solving differential equations for simple harmonic motion and analyzing the result.

potential_energy_functions.title: Potential Energy Functions
potential_energy_functions.notes: This is actually a step towards the field of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.

voltage_and_current_concepts.title: Voltage and Current Concepts
voltage_and_current_concepts.note: 8-21-19 i feel like parallel circuit concepts and short circuit concepts belong in a different quiz ladder, and there need to be more quiz ladders on circuits certainly

very_basic_atoms.title: Very Basic Atoms
very_basic_atoms.objective: Draw and explain atomic structure; recognize AC and DC current; explain why specific electrons move

circuit_definitions_1.title: Circuit Definitions 1: Multiple Choice
circuit_definitions_1.objective: Recognize the definitions and properties of voltage, current, resistance, and power.

energy_change_in_circuit.title: Energy Change in a Circuit
energy_change_in_circuit.objective: Describe how energy changes in an electric circuit consisting of only a battery, a lightbulb, and a wire.

circuit_definitions_2.title: Circuit Definitions 2: Open Response
circuit_definitions_2.objective: Memorize the definitions and properties of voltage, current, resistance, and power.

organization_atoms.title: Organization of Atoms
organization_atoms.objective: Draw how atoms are organized in insulators and conductors; relate this organization to how circuits operate within an electric circuit; explain why electrons and not protons and neutrons move in an electric circuit.

advanced_current_1.title: Advanced Current 1: How do Electrons Move
advanced_current_1.objective: Differentiate between two theories of electron motion, one in which electrons all come from the battery and one in which they remain in the wire, select the theory, argue that electrons move slowly through a circuit

advanced_voltage_1.title: Advanced Voltage 1: The Potato Battery
advanced_voltage_1.objective: Explain by referring to chemical princples why a potato battery lights a clock; explain why a bulb lights instantly when connected to a battery.

advanced_current_2.title: Advanced Current 2: Implications of How Electrons Move
advanced_current_2.objective: Refer to concepts of how electrons move to explain how current changes in circuits with switches and resistors
advanced_current_2.note: Address misconception that closer light bulbs will be brighter.

advanced_current_3.title: Advanced Current 3: Conventional Current
advanced_current_3.objective: Untangle the conundrum that, mathematically, current flows the opposite way that electrons actually move.

advanced_current_4.title: Advanced Current 4: Electron Drift and Charge of a Wire
advanced_current_4.objective: Describe how electrons combine fast random motion with slow drift under and electric field; describe how an electric wire has a neutral charge.

advanced_current_5.title: Advanced Current 5: Summation of Charge Motion
advanced_current_5.objective: Describe current and the summation of motion of many charges, relate current to the total number of free-charges in a wire; differentaite between free and not-free electrons in a wire.

advanced_voltage_2.title: Advanced Voltage 2: Battery Chemistry
advanced_voltage_2.objective: Relate specific batteries to half-reactions and explain how electric current flows through the electrolyte

advanced_current_6.title: Advanced Current 6: Electricity without Electrons
advanced_current_6.objective: Describe how current can flow in bodies with charged particles other than water, such as a solution of ions.

rigorous_definition_current.title: The Rigorous Definition of Current
rigorous_definition_current.objective: Describe current at a point as charge per time through that point; explain an equation that relates electron drift velocity to current.

rigorous_definition_voltage.title: The Rigorous Definition of Voltage
rigorous_definition_voltage.objective: Describe Potential Difference between two points across a resistor as energy per charge.

rigorous_batteries.title: Rigorous Batteries
rigorous_batteries.objective: Apply rigorous definitions of current and voltage to a battery

rigorous_definition_power.title: Rigorous Definition of Power
rigorous_definition_power.objective: Describe power as energy inputted or outputted into a circuit per unit time and explain how the power formula is consistent with definitions of current and potential difference.

advanced_current_x.title: Advanced Current 4: Current Model
advanced_current_x.objective: Design a physical model, such as a diagram, a video, or a skit, that accurately describes the motion of electrons on a complex circuit with mulitple resistors and switches in series and parallel.

dc_circuit_math_1.title: DC Circuit Math 1: Batteries and Resistors
dc_circuit_math_1.limits: Only contains circuits including batteries and resistors

ohms_law.title: Ohm's Law
ohms_law.objective: Solve Ohm's law for either resistance, current, or voltage.
ohms_law.content: Voltage is equal to current times resistance.

power_formula.title: The Power Formula
power_formula.objective: Use both the power formula and Ohm's Law to solve for power or other quantities.
power_formula.content: Power is equal to current times voltage; this formula can be combined with Ohm's Law.

analyze_circuits_1.title: Analyze Circuits 1
analyze_circuits_1.objective: Use a table to find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of a simple series or parallel circuit; begin from the voltage of the battery and the resistance of each resistor.
analyze_circuits_1.content: Set rules and formulas can find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element of a series or parallel circuit.

analyze_circuits_2.title: Analyze Circuits 2
analyze_circuits_2.objective: Use a table to find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of a simple series or parallel circuit; begin from any information.
analyze_circuits_2.content: Set rules and formulas can find the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element of a series or parallel circuit, and you can logically deduce the information you need from different sets of initial information.

algebraic_circuits_1.title: Algebraic Circuits 1
algebraic_circuits_1.subtitle: New Circuit Formulas
algebraic_circuits_1.objective: Know dimensions of voltage, current, resistance, and power; algebraically manipulate and solve Ohm's Law and the Power formula separately and together
algebraic_circuits_1.content: Ohm's Law and the Power Formula can be manipulated to create new formulas.

electric_potential_diagrams_1.title: Electric Potential Diagrams 1
electric_potential_diagrams_1.objective: Draw graphs depicting how electric potential within a circuit changes across each element for simple series and parallel circuits.
electric_potential_diagrams_1.content: Voltage can be depicted as changes in electric potential across a circuit; magnitude of current can also be depicted on an electric potential graph.

analyze_circuits_3.title: Analyze Circuits 3: One-Step Accordion Circuits
analyze_circuits_3.objective: Solve circuits with series components inside of parallel components or parallel sections in series.
analyze_circuits_3.content: Combinations of series and parallel resistor elements can be combined and taken apart to make a circuit.

electric_potential_diagrams_2.title: Electric Potential Diagrams 2
electric_potential_diagrams_2.objective: Given an electric potential diagram of a circuit, draw a circuit that could potentially be the correct circuit.
electric_potential_diagrams_2.content: The elements within a circuit can be determined from an electric potential diagram of that circuit.

algebraic_circuits_2.title: Algebraic Circuits 2
algebraic_circuits_2.subtitle: Solving Series and Parallel Circuits Algebraically
algebraic_circuits_2.objective: Algebraically determine voltage, current, resistance, and power of a circuit with only series and parallel elements; derive the formula for total resistance in a parallel circuit.

analyze_circuits_4.title: Analyze Circuits 4
analyze_circuits_4.subtitle: Demonstrating Kirchoff's Laws
analyze_circuits_4.objective: For circuits with multiple layers of series and parallel elements within each other, determine the voltage, current, resistance, and power of each element and draw a diagram illustrating the electric potential of the circuit, and describe how the circuit diagram drawn illustrates Kirchoff's Laws.

dc_circuit_dimensional_analysis.title: DC Circuit Dimensional Analysis
dc_circuit_dimensional_analysis.objective: Determine and explain the units of all DC circuit quantities; prove various formulas are dimensionally correct.

algebraic_circuits_3.title: Algebraic Circuits 3
algebraic_circuits_3.subtitle: Solving Accordion Circuits Algebraically and Dimensional Analysis with Circuits
algebraic_circuits_3.objective: Algebraically solve circuits with series and parallel elements inside each other; demonstrate that the answers are dimensionally correct.

mathematically_rigorous_circuit_model.title: Mathematically Rigorous Circuit Model
mathematically_rigorous_circuit_model.objective: Define and use mathematically rigorous definitions of potential difference, current, resistance, and power; use Kirchoff's Laws to demonstrate basic circuit rules.

resistor_only_design.title: DC Circuit Design: Resistors Only
resistor_only_design.objective: Given a particular design goal, combine a set of resistors to accomplish this goal.

electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.title: Electromagnetic vs. Mechanical Waves 1
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.objective: Recognize electromagnetic and mechanical waves from a list; answer multiple choice questions on differences between electromagnetic and mechanical waves.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_1.content: All waves can be categorized as either electromagnetic waves or mechanical waves.

transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.title: Transverse vs. Longitudinal Waves
transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.objective: Differentiate between pictures and examples of transverse and longitudinal waves.
transverse_vs_longitudinal_waves.content: All waves can be categorized as either transverse or longitudinal waves.

parts_of_a_wave_1.title: Parts of a Wave 1: Transverse Waves
parts_of_a_wave_1.objective: Identify important parts of a traveling transverse wave, including crests, troughs, wavelength, and amplitude.
parts_of_a_wave_1.content: Crests, troughs, wavelength, and amplitude are important elements of a transverse wave.

drawing_waves_1A.title: Drawing Waves 1A: Wavelength
drawing_waves_1A.objective: Draw transverse waves with a particular wavelength and each crest correctly positioned
drawing_waves_1A.content: The distance between the crests of a transverse wave show its wavelength.

drawing_waves_1B.title: Drawing Waves 1B: Amplitude
drawing_waves_1B.objective: Draw transverse waves with a particular amplitude.
drawing_waves_1B.content: The distance from the middle of a transverse wave to its crest shows its amplitude.

wave_equation.title: The Wave Equation
wave_equation.objective: Use the equation v = lambda f in simple contexts related to waves.
wave_equation.content: The speed of a wave is equal to its wavelength times its frequency.

electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.title: Electromagnetic vs. Mechanical Waves 2
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.objective: Write definitions of electromagnetic and mechanical waves; write differences between electromagnetic and mechanical waves.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.notes: This is the quiz in which students formally define a wave.
electromagnetic_vs_mechanical_waves_2.content: Mechanical waves consist of moving oscillations; electromagnetic wave consist of oscillating electric and magnetic energy.

oscillation_particles_during_wave.title: Oscillation of Particles During a Wave
oscillation_particles_during_wave.objective: Diagram how an object oscillates as a mechanical transverse or longitudinal wave passes through.
oscillation_particles_during_wave.content: As a wave passes through, the direction a particle oscillates depends on whether it is a transverse or mechanical wave.

wave_categorization.title: Wave Categorization
wave_categorization.objective: Categorize waves using a matrix as electromagnetic or mechanical and as longitudinal or transverse.
wave_categorization.content: Waves can be categorized as transverse electromagnetic waves, transverse mechanical waves, or longitudinal mechanical waves.

parts_of_a_wave_2.title: Parts of a Wave 2: Longitudinal Waves
parts_of_a_wave_2.objective: Identify parts of a longitudinal wave, including compression zone, rarefaction zone, and wavelength; briefly measure wavelength and amplitude of a longitudinal wave.
parts_of_a_wave_2.content: The crest of a transverse wave corresponds to the compression zone of a longitudinal wave; the trough of a longitudinal wave corresponds to the rarefaction zone of a longitudinal wave; wavelength and amplitude can be measured on an image of a longitudinal wave.

speed_of_sound_and_light_1.title: Speed of Sound and Light 1
speed_of_sound_and_light_1.objective: Identify the difference between the speeds of sound and light; identify real world implications of this.
speed_of_sound_and_light_1.content: Sound moves much slower than light, and this fact can be observed whenever a loud sound is made far away.

drawing_waves_2.title: Drawing Waves 2: Wavelength and amplitude
drawing_waves_2.objective: Draw waves of particular wavelength AND amplitude, with a particular focus on the crests of a wave.
drawing_waves_2.limits: Grading is generous if the troughs of a wave are not perfectly drawn.
drawing_waves_2.content: Wavelength and amplitude can be depicted on an image of a wave.

making_transverse_longitudinal_waves.title: Making Transverse and Longitudinal Waves
making_transverse_longitudinal_waves.objective: Explain how to create transverse and longitudinal waves in multiple contexts; explain logically why sound is longitudinal and light is transverse.

drawing_waves_3.title: Drawing Waves 3: Crests and Troughs positioned
drawing_waves_3.objective: Draw waves of particular wavelength AND ampltidue with every crest, trough, and center point correctly positioned.
drawing_waves_3.note: Crest, troughs, and middle points must all be correctly positoned, horizontally and vertically, for full credit.

speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.title: Speed of Sound and Light in Media
speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.objective: Identify how media change the speed of sound and the speed of light; identify why media has opposite effects on the speed of sound and of light.
speed_of_sound_and_light_in_media.notes: Also deals with the ideas of transverse and longitudinal waves..

trigonometric_waves_1.title: Trigonometric Waves 1
trigonometric_waves_1.objective: Write trigonometric functions that show the shape of a wave with a particular wavelength and amplitude

drawing_waves_4.title: Drawing Waves 4: Phase
drawing_waves_4.objective: Draw waves with a particular wavelength, amplitude, and phase, with all crests, troughs, and center points drawn correctly.
drawing_waves_4.notes: The wave must begin on a particular phase for full credit. Phases presented are 0, pi/2, pi, and 3pi/2

trigonometric_waves_2.title: Trigonometric Waves 2
trigonometric_waves_2.objective: Write trigonometric functions that show the shape of a wave with a particular wavelength and amplitude

trigonometric_waves_3.title: Trigonometric Waves 3
trigonometric_waves_3.objective: Write a trigonometric function that gives the position of a particle relative to time as a transverse wave passes through. Identify and explain pieces of this function.

doppler_diagrams.objective: Analyze diagrams of a wave front of sound; explain why the Doppler effect occurs.

explain_speed_of_sound.title: Explain The Speed of Sound
explain_speed_of_sound.objective: Explain why the speed of sound changes within different media.

doppler_algebra.title: Doppler Algebra
doppler_algebra.objective: Algebraically solve the Doppler effect equation.

doppler_proportionality.title: Doppler Proportionality
doppler_proportionality.objective: Use proportionality to analyze the Doppler effect equation.

sound_barrier.title: The Sound Barrier
sound_barrier.objective: Use diagrams of sound waves to explain the existence of the sound barrier, and what occurs when it is broken.

wave_phenomena_basics.objective: Identify real-world examples of reflection, refraction, interference, scattering, diffraction, and absorpotion of waves.

diffraction_scattering_diagrams.objective: Draw diagrams that illustrate the phenomena of diffraction and scattering.

interference_diagrams_2.title: Interference Diagrams 2: Interference in Non-Regularly Shaped Waves
interference_diagrams_2.objective: Draw and recognize diagrams that show non-regular examples of waves passing through each other.

huygens_principle.title: Huygen's Principle

diffraction_grating_diagram.title: Diffraction Grating Diagrams

diffraction_grating_formula.title: Diffraction Grating Formula
diffraction_grating_formula.objective: Use the diffraciton grating formula to derive the wavelength of light.

discovery_of_dna_structure.title: Discovery of the DNA Structure
discovery_of_dna_structure.objective: Using a diagram of X-Ray diffraction, describe the structure of DNA and defend your answer.

rainbows_quantitative.title: Rainbows Quantitative
rainbows_quantitative.objective: Use Snell's Law and diagrams of refraction and reflection to quantiatively and qualitatively explain how a rainbow is made from raindrops.

the_electromagnetic_spectrum_quantitativ.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum: Quantitative
enduring_understandings: The electromagnetic spectrum contains seven types of electromagnetic waves, including visible light.
While all waves are experienced and applied in qualitatively different waves, they are all the same thing: oscillating electric and magnetic energy.
The only true differences amongst electromagnetic waves are quantitative values: wavelength, frequency, and photon energy
These three values are related by fundamental constants.
Frequency and energy are directly proportional, while wavelength is inversely proportional to both.

electromagnetic_wave_basics.title: Electromagnetic Wave Basics
electromagnetic_wave_basics.objective: Remember basic facts about electromagnetic waves.
electromagnetic_wave_basics.content: Electromagnetic waves are oscillations of electric and magnetic energy; all electromagnetic waves move at 300,000,000 m/s; electromagnetic waves can move through vacuums; electromagnetic waves are transverse.

electromagnetic_spectrum_1.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum 1
electromagnetic_spectrum_1.objective: Memorize the Electromagnetic Spectrum and the colors separately in order from longest to shortest wavelength; relate different waves using the terms wavelength and frequency
electromagnetic_spectrum_1.content: Each color has a specific wavelength and frequency that defines that color; each type of electromagnetic wave has a specific wavelength and frequency that define that wave; wavelength and frequency are inversely proportional

choosing_color_by_wavelength.title: Choosing Colors by Wavelength
choosing_color_by_wavelength.objective: For visible electromagnetic waves of specific wavelengths, determine the color of that wave.
choosing_color_by_wavelength.content: The wavelength of each electromagnetic wave determines what color that wave is; visible light spans from 400 nm to 700 nm

electromagnetic_spectrum_2.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum 2
electromagnetic_spectrum_2.objective: Memorize the Electromagnetic Spectrum and colors as a single spectrum in order from longest to shortest wavelength; relate different waves using the terms wavelength, frequency, and energy (short answer).
electromagnetic_spectrum_2.content: The electromagnetic spectrum can be broken into six invisible waves and six visible colors; these categories have different wavelength, frequency, and energy; all electromagnetic waves have the same speed.

classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.title: Classify Electromagnetic Wave by Wavelength 1
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.subtitle: Scientific Notation
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.objective: Given a wave of a particular wavelength of any order of magnitude, determine what type of electromagnetic wave is represented.
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.limits: All values are given in SI scientific notation and not in metric units
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.content: Any electromagnetic wave is categorized into a particular type by its wavelength; wavelength can span from over one meter to 10^-12 m, so a through knowledge of scientific notation is necessary to properly categorize waves.

classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.title: Classify Electromagnetic Wave by Wavelength 2
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.subtitle: Metric Units
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.objective: Given a wave of a particular wavelength of any order of magnitude, determine what type of electromagnetic wave is represented.
classify_electromagnetic_wave_by_wavelen.content: The wavelength of an electromagnetic wave can is frequently expressed in metric units; by understanding these metric units a physicist can better classify electromagnetic waves.

photon_formulas_1.title: Photon Formulas 1
photon_formulas_1.objective: Quantitatively relate wavelength, frequency, and photon energy of a wave; problems presented step by step
photon_formulas_1.content: Physicists use two key formulas to relate the wavelength, frequency, and energy of an electromagnetic photon.

electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.title: Electromagnetic Wave Proportionality
electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.objective: Relate wavelength, frequency, and energy of waves using proportionality rules.
electromagnetic_wave_proportionality.content: The energy of an electromagnetic photon is directly proportional to its frequency and inversely proportional to its wavelength; a physicist can use these relationships to better comprehend electromagnetic waves.

photon_formulas_2.title: Photon Formulas 2
photon_formulas_2.objective: Quantitatively relate wavelength, frequency, and photon energy of a wave; problems are asked in all directions in tabular form
photon_formulas_2.content: Because the wavelength, frequency, and energy electromagnetic photons comprise such as wide range of magnitudes, rarely used metric units are frequently used to express them; these units must be properly converted before and after using any formula

logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.title: Logarithmic Graph of the Electromagnetic Spectrum 1
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.objective: Create a logarithmic axis which shows the range of each type of electromagnetic wave with scales in terms of ONE of the following: wavelength, energy, and frequency; express the logarithmic value on the axis
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.content: Due to the wide range of wavelengths in the electromagnetic spectrum, the electromagnetic spectrum can only be properly visualized on a logarithmic scale

logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.title: Logarithmic Graph of the EM Spectrum 2
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.objective: Create a logarithmic axis which shows the range of each type of electromagnetic wave with scales in terms of ALL THREE of the following: wavelength, energy, and frequency; express graph using a logarithmic scale but numbers written in linear
logarithmic_graph_electromagnetic_spectr.content: A logarithmic scale can be used to describe the electromagnetic spectrum using either wavelength, frequency, or photon energy as a categorizing quantity.

space_photos.title: Space Photos
space_photos.objective: Explain, and do some examples, how photos are made of non-visible light objects in space.
space_photos.content: NASA and similar organizations collect vast amounts of numerical data from telescopes; beautiful photos that are publicized as space are often constructed by correlating invisible electromagnetic wavelengths to visible ones.

visible_light_human_experience.title: Visible Light and the Human Experience
visible_light_human_experience.objective: From your knowledge of the electromagnetic spectrum, surmise philosophical conclusions on the human experience and the role of humans in the universe.
visible_light_human_experience.content: The human eye reacts to an almost immeasurably  tiny portion of the electromagnetic spectrum; philosophers seeking to understand humanity's place int he universe must contend with this fact.

the_electromagnetic_spectrum_conceptual.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum: Conceptual

basic_infrared_camera.objective: Explain an infrared camera very simply.
examples: Why do humans appear white on an infrared camera?
Why does ice appear black on an infrared camera?

reflection_color.title: Reflection and Color
reflection_color.objective: Predict how objects of different color will reflect different photons of light.

additive_color.title: Additive Color
additive_color.objective: Explain how colors of light combine to make different colors; relate this fact to light from the sun and flourescent lights

long_vs_short_wavelength.title: Long vs. Short Wavelength
long_vs_short_wavelength.objective: Identify long and short wavelength electromagnetic waves and explain difference in how they would interact.

infrared_camera_advanced.objective: Explain how different objects emit different wavelengths; ex
examples: The wires inside a toaster appear red, why?
How are the wires inside of a toaster similar to humans, how are they different, and how can different types of camera examine this difference.
How do objects of different human color appear on an infrared camera.

define_radiation.title: Define Radioactivity
define_radiation.objective: Define all the terms that make electromagnetic waves seem scary, such as radioactivity; analyze the relative value of these terms.

safe_and_dangerous_waves.title: Safe and dangerous waves
safe_and_dangerous_waves.objective: Explain what makes some waves safe and others dangerous. Identify safe and dangerous waves.

subtractive_color.title: Subtractive Color
subtractive_color.objective: Explain how colors of paint combine and relate this to knowledge about how light combines and how reflection produces color.

identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.title: Identify Applications of Electromagnetic Waves
identify_applications_electromagnetic_wa.objective: In writing, identify human applications each of types of invisible electromagnetic waves; relate the particular uses of each wave to wavelength, frequency and energy
examples: What types of wave are most used for communication and why?
How does X-rays allow you to see within your body?
Which types of waves are dangerous and why?
Can dangerous waves be useful, and how.

long_wavelength_astronomy.title: Long Wavelength Astronomy
long_wavelength_astronomy.objective: Explain how astronomers conduct astronomy in the radio, microwave and infrared ranges and what objects they see in these ranges.

short_wavelength_astronomy.title: Short Wavelength Astronomy
short_wavelength_astronomy.objective: Explain how astronomers conduct astronomy in the visible, ultraviolet, X-Ray and gamma ray ranges and what objects they see in these ranges.

why_is_the_sky_blue.title: Why is the sky blue?
why_is_the_sky_blue.objective: Use basic principles of electromagnetic waves, especially long and short wavelengths, and human vision to explain why the sky is blue.

climate_change.title: Climate Change
climate_change.objective: Explain why the greenhouse effect occurs and explain positive and negative results of the greenhouse effect.

galaxy_in_all_wavelengths.title: A Galaxy in All Wavelengths
galaxy_in_all_wavelengths.objective: Examine photos of astronomical bodies in each region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

electromagnetic_rube_goldberg_device.title: Electromagnetic Rube Goldberg Device
electromagnetic_rube_goldberg_device.objective: Design a hypothetical device that uses each different type of electromagnetic wave to accomplish a small household task.

lens_mirror_equations_1.objective: Predict the location of an image from the position of an object and the focal length of a lens or mirror.

lens_mirror_equations_2.title: Lens and Mirror Equations 2

mirror_2.title: Mirror 2: Concave Mirror Object inside of Focal Range
mirror_2.objective: Draw a ray diagram for a concave mirror with an object inside the focal range
